                                                        [1;4mCreating Code with Python[0m                                                         

[1;33m â€¢ [0mVS Code is a special type of text editor that is called a compiler. At the top, youâ€™ll notice a text editor and, at the bottom you will
[1;33m   [0msee a terminal where you can execute commands.                                                                                         
[1;33m â€¢ [0mIn the terminal, you can execute [97;40mcode hello.py[0m to start coding.                                                                        
[1;33m â€¢ [0mIn the text editor above, you can type [97;40mprint("hello, world")[0m . This is a famous canonical program that nearly all coders write during  
[1;33m   [0mtheir learning process.                                                                                                                
[1;33m â€¢ [0mIn the terminal window, you can execute commands. To run this program, you are going to need to move your cursor to the bottom of the  
[1;33m   [0mscreen, clicking in the terminal window. You can now type a second command in the terminal window. Next to the dollar sign, type [97;40mpython[0m
[1;33m   [0m[97;40mhello.py[0m and press the enter key on your keyboard.                                                                                     
[1;33m â€¢ [0mRecall, computers really only understand zeros and ones. Therefore, when you run [97;40mpython hello.py[0m , python will interpret the text that 
[1;33m   [0myou created in [97;40mhello.py[0m and translate it into the zeros and ones that the computer can understand.                                     
[1;33m â€¢ [0mThe result of running the [97;40mpython hello.py[0m program is [97;40mhello, world[0m .                                                                    
[1;33m â€¢ [0mCongrats! You just created your first program.                                                                                         


                                                                [1;4mFunctions[0m                                                                 

[1;33m â€¢ [0mFunctions are verbs or actions that the computer or computer language will already know how to perform.                                
[1;33m â€¢ [0mIn your [97;40mhello.py[0m program, the [97;40mprint[0m function knows how to print to the terminal window.                                                
[1;33m â€¢ [0mThe [97;40mprint[0m function takes arguments. In this case, [97;40m"hello, world"[0m are the arguments that the [97;40mprint[0m function takes.                      


                                                                   [1;4mBugs[0m                                                                   

[1;33m â€¢ [0mBugs are a natural part of coding. These are mistakes, problems for you to solve! Donâ€™t get discouraged! This is part of the process of
[1;33m   [0mbecoming a great programmer.                                                                                                           
[1;33m â€¢ [0mImagine in our [97;40mhello.py[0m program that accidentally typed [97;40mprint("hello, world"[0m notice that we missed the final [97;40m)[0m required by the         
[1;33m   [0mcompiler. If I purposefully make this mistake, youâ€™ll the compiler will output an error in the terminal window!                        
[1;33m â€¢ [0mOften, the error messages will inform you of your mistake and provide you clues on how to fix them. However, there will be many times  
[1;33m   [0mthat the compiler is not this kind.

literally assigns what is on the right to what is on the left. Therefore, the value returned by [97;40minput("What's your name? ")[0m is assigned to
[97;40mname[0m .

Comments                                                                                                                                  

[1;33m â€¢ [0mComments are a way for programmers to track what they are doing in their programs and even inform others about their intentions for a  
[1;33m   [0mblock of code. In short, they are notes for yourself and others that will see your code!                                               
[1;33m â€¢ [0mYou can add comments to your program to be able to see what it is that your program is doing. You might edit your code as follows:

[1;33m â€¢ [0mFunctions take arguments that influence their behavior. If we look at the documentation for ]8;id=622313;https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#print\[97;40mprint[0m]8;;\ youâ€™ll notice we can learn a lot     
[1;33m   [0mabout the arguments that the print function takes.                                                                                     
[1;33m â€¢ [0mLooking at this documentation, youâ€™ll learn that the print function automatically include a piece of code [97;40mend='\n'. This[0m \n [97;40mindicates [0m 
[1;33m   [0m[97;40mthat the print function will automatically create a line break when run. The print function takes an argument called[0m end` and the      
[1;33m   [0mdefault is to create a new line.                                                                                                       
[1;33m â€¢ [0mHowever, we can technically provide an argument for [97;40mend[0m ourselves such that a new line is not created!                                 
[1;33m â€¢ [0mWe can modify our code as follows:                                                                                                     

[2mâ”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”[0m

By providing [97;40mend=""[0m we are over-writing the default value of [97;40mend[0m such that it never creates a new line after this first print statement.  
Providing the name as â€œDavidâ€, the output in the terminal window will be [97;40mhello, David[0m .                                                   

[1;33m â€¢ [0mParameters, therefore, are arguments that can be taken by a function.                                                                  
[1;33m â€¢ [0mYou can learn more in Pythonâ€™s documentation on ]8;id=299758;https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#print\[97;40mprint[0m]8;;\ .                                                                                

                                                                                                                                          

A small problem with quotation marks                                                                                                      

[1;33m â€¢ [0mNotice how adding quotation marks as part of your string is challenging.                                                               
[1;33m â€¢ [0m[97;40mprint("hello,"friend"")[0m will not work and the compiler will throw an error.                                                            
[1;33m â€¢ [0mGenerally, there are two approaches to fixing this. First, you could simply change the quotes to single quote marks.                   
[1;33m â€¢ [0mAnother, more commonly used approach would be code as [97;40mprint("hello, \"friend\"")[0m . The backslashes tell the compiler that the following
[1;33m   [0mcharacter should be considered a quotation mark in the string and avoid a compiler error.                                              


                                                            [1;4mFormatting Strings[0m                                                            

[1;33m â€¢ [0mProbably the most elegant way to use strings would be as follows:

[1;33m â€¢ [0mRunning this program, we discover that the output is incorrect as [97;40m12[0m . Why might this be?

[1;33m   [0mcompiler as text, it is treated a string. We, therefore, need to convert this input from a string to an integer. We can do so as

The result is now correct. The use of [97;40mint(x)[0m , is called â€œcastingâ€ where a value is temporarily changed from one type of variable (in this
case a string) to another (here, an integer).

[97;40minput[0m function is run. Then, the [97;40mint[0m function.

                                                             [1;4mReadability Wins[0m                                                             

[1;33m â€¢ [0mWhen deciding on your approach to a coding task, remember that one could make a reasonable argument for many approaches to the same    
[1;33m   [0mproblem.                                                                                                                               
[1;33m â€¢ [0mRegardless of what approach you take to a programming task, remember that your code must be readable. You should use comments to give  
[1;33m   [0myourself and others clues about what your code is doing. Further, you should create code in a way that is readable.                    


                                                               [1;4mFloat Basics[0m

Notice that everything under [97;40mdef hello()[0m is indented. Python is an indented language. It uses indentation to understand what is part of   
the above function. Therefore, everything in the [97;40mhello[0m function must be indented. When something is not indented, it treats it as if it is
not inside the [97;40mhello[0m function. Running [97;40mpython hello.py[0m in the terminal window, youâ€™ll see that your output is not exactly as you may want.

a single parameter: a variable called [97;40mto[0m . Therefore, when you call [97;40mhello(name)[0m the computer passes [97;40mname[0m into the [97;40mhello[0m function as [97;40mto[0m .
